misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that closing a Scanner object is a necessary local cleanup procedure to 'finish' the input process, similar to closing a file handle to save it or free memory.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, closing a Scanner that wraps System.in also closes the underlying standard input stream. While not fatal in this single-method program, it is a flawed mental model because System.in is a global resource; closing it prevents any other part of the program from ever reading input again during that execution.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Runtime exception (NoSuchElementException or IllegalStateException) if any subsequent code attempted to read from the console.

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that the computer relies on English descriptive prompts and step-by-step numbered comments to maintain the logical sequence and understand the purpose of each input block.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student numbers their comments 'Step 1' through 'Step 8' and explicitly describes the 'asking' and 'looping' to the machine. The notional machine, however, only executes the bytecode instructions and ignores comments and the semantic meaning of prompt strings.

evidence.code_snippet: // Step 1: Ask the user to enter the size of the array
// Step 3: Ask the user to enter the elements of the array
